summary: the introduction rubella virus (RV) is the only member of the Rubivirus genus in the family togaviridae. it acts as an extremely efficient teratogen when infection occurs during the first trimester of pregnancy. RV-induced apoptosis occurs in a complex, multi-step and rather cell type-specific manner. mitochondrial permeabilization is characterized by formation of mitochondrial apoptosis-induced channel (MAC) and the relatively large mitochondrial permeability transition pore (mPTP), which originates at the IMM. mitochondrial function is lost and the apoptotic cascade is further fueled, as metabolites, small ions and apoptogenic factors are released. cyclophilins as proteins of the peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase (PPIase) family are highly conserved molecular chaperons that support protein
